intro: Aethusa cynapium var. pygmaea, commonly known as the dwarf hemlock, is a small, herbaceous plant belonging to the Apiaceae family. It is native to parts of Europe and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of only a few inches, making it a compact and delicate species. It prefers moist, shady environments and is often found in woodland areas. Its botanical structure reflects adaptations to its specific ecological niche, with a short stature and clustered growth habit.
